an4.108:1.1: “Mendicants, there are these four kinds of oxen.
an4.108:1.3: One hostile to its own herd, not others;
an4.108:1.4: one hostile to other herds, not its own;
an4.108:1.5: one hostile to both its own herd and others; and
an4.108:1.6: one hostile to neither its own herd nor others.
an4.108:1.7: These are the four kinds of oxen.
an4.108:1.8: In the same way, these four people similar to oxen are found in the world.
an4.108:1.10: One hostile to their own herd, not others;
an4.108:1.11: one hostile to other herds, not their own;
an4.108:1.12: one hostile to both their own herd and others; and
an4.108:1.13: one hostile to neither their own herd nor others.
an4.108:2.1: And how is a person hostile to their own herd, not others?
an4.108:2.2: It’s when a person intimidates their own followers, not the followers of others.
an4.108:2.3: That’s how a person is hostile to their own herd, not others.
an4.108:2.4: That person is like an ox that’s hostile to its own herd, not others.
an4.108:3.1: And how is a person hostile to other herds, not their own?
an4.108:3.2: It’s when a person intimidates the followers of others, not their own. …
an4.108:4.1: And how is a person hostile to both their own herd and others?
an4.108:4.2: It’s when a person intimidates their own followers and the followers of others. …
an4.108:5.1: And how is a person hostile to neither their own herd nor others?
an4.108:5.2: It’s when a person doesn’t intimidate their own followers or the followers of others.
an4.108:5.6: These four people similar to oxen are found in the world.”
